Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Catalyzing Polymerization in the Laboratory and Discussion in the Classroom with Artificial Metalloenzymes
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jared C. Lewis at the University of Chicago is developing artificial metalloenzymes (ArMs) comprised of olefin polymerization catalysts covalently linked to protein scaffolds to control polyolefin structure and function. This research involves the synthesis of cofactors based on known olefin polymerization catalysts, the design and expression of different protein scaffolds, and the bioconjugation of different scaffolds using synthetic cofactors to generate the proposed ArMs. Detailed characterization of ArM structure is being pursued using spectroscopic methods and X-ray crystallography at Argonne National Labs. The ability of these ArMs to catalyze olefin polymerization is being explored, and a combination of rational design and directed evolution is being used to optimize the observed activity and selectivity. Given the importance of polyolefins in every day life, this ArM polymerization catalyst development program is being leveraged to develop teaching modules on chemistry, catalysis, and materials with local middle school (Grade 8) students at the Irene C. Hernandez Middle School for the Advancement of the Sciences (HMS). This will provide HMS students with additional curriculum-relevant discussion of materials chemistry and University of Chicago students with real world opportunities for explaining science and receiving feedback on their teaching. The broader impacts of this work include the potential for discovering new mechanisms to control polymer structure and function, new functional polymers, and unique training opportunities for students and postdocs at the interface of chemistry and protein engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polyolefins are ubiquitous. Found in products ranging from food packaging and garbage bags to photovoltaic devices and synthetic organs, these materials are critical to human health, quality of life, and the global economy. The different properties of the aforementioned products are determined by polyolefin structure, which is in turn determined by the olefin building blocks and catalysts employed in polymerization processes. Thus, continued identification of advanced materials requires new, selective polymerization catalysts. The initial goal of this CAREER proposal was to develop artificial metalloenzymes (ArMs) comprised of olefin polymerization catalysts ensconced within evolvable protein scaffolds to control polyolefin structure and function. During the course of the award, its focus was expanded to include a variety of olefin functionalization methods in addition to polymerization. Given the importance of polyolefins in every day life, however, our ArM program was leveraged to develop teaching modules on chemistry, catalysis, and materials with local middle school (Grade 8) students at the Irene C. Hernandez Middle School for the Advancement of the Sciences (HMS). Our involvement provided HMS students with additional curriculum-relevant discussion of materials chemistry and University of Chicago students with real world opportunities for explaining science and receiving feedback on their teaching. 

During the course of the award, undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers received training in organic and organometallic synthesis, molecular and microbiology, advanced bioconjugation methods, high throughput experimentation, directed evolution, and catalysis. The most fundamental advance made involved detailed characterization of Pyrococcus furiosus (Pfu) prolyl oligopeptidase (POP). Our studies established the importance of spontaneous interdomain opening/closing on the ability of this enzyme to hydrolyze peptide substrates. Importantly, this finding also provided insight into why Pfu POP could be readily modified using bulky synthetic cofactors within its active site (when open) yet still provide a hydrophobic cavity in which selective catalysis can occur (when closed). We used an acridinium cofactor to both probe active site hydrophobicity and establish the first example of ArM photoredox catalysis (for sulfide oxidation). We also established that rational active site design could be used to develop the first highly selective ArMs for olefin cyclopropanation using a dirhodium cofactor. Based on this effort, we then developed a robust protocol for ArM evolution, which led to the first examples of ArM evolution using random mutagenesis. This ability dramatically simplified our ArM engineering efforts and forms the basis of all ArM research ongoing in the group. Most recently, we have established that Pfu POP can directly bind to metal polypyridyl complexes to modulate metal polypyridyl photophysical properties and to enable non-covalent ArM formation. These ArMs are competent photoredox catalysts for a variety of transformations, and ongoing efforts are focused on evolving these systems for selective olefin functionalization. These studies have resulted in seven peer reviewed publications to date. Three additional projects that were started using funded from this award are ongoing (including the original olefin polymerization effort), will be published in due course, and will acknowledge this funding.
